title: Tuesday, 11th July, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Hi there. Welcome to Markets Live

PM11:02am

This bond sell of has been rumbling on -- and not really affecting equites

PM11:03am

But suddenly it is, perhaps

11:02 am
PM11:03am

PM11:03am

That's the German 10 year

PM11:03am

Yield has doubled this month

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Anyway, Footsie off 57 points currently

PM11:04am

We need to keep an eye on all this

PM11:04am

Red -- why 2.423 precisely?

11:04 am
PM11:05am

Boncoeur -- We change our tune with some regularity, you may have noticed

PM11:05am

But let's go to the features...

undefined
11:05 am
Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 647.50, down 43 (-6.23%), High: 713.00, Low: 633.00, Volume: 5.04m
PM11:05am

Market cottoning on here

PM11:06am

What Fallon does is throw assets out of the boat to keep it afloat

11:06 am
PM11:06am

But the reversal in Pearson this morning really eye catching

BE11:06am

Well ............... I've wasted far too much time trying to get my head around what Pearson's actually said this morning.

BE11:06am

I mean, the headlines are straightforward.

11:06 am
BE11:07am

Disposal of 22% stake in Random Pengun, net proceeds of $968m (including dividends on a re-cap).

BE11:07am

Further dividend of $66m in April 2018

BE11:07am

The price is okay. 1.05x 2016 sales or 7x 2016 EV/EBITDA

11:07 am
BE11:07am

What's a bit less okay is the "£840m in, £300m" out thing.

BE11:08am

£300m to be returned to shareholders via buyback.

PM11:08am

this is what caused the price reversal, yes?

11:08 am
PM11:08am

Stock ran up to 713p first thing

PM11:08am

Reversed course when everyone realised the "£840m in, £300m" thing = worries about the balance sheeet

BE11:09am

Well, in part. And in that context the more concerning line is the guidance for "a comfortably covered dividend".

11:09 am
BE11:09am

What does that mean? So Pearson has already flagged that the divi's getting rebased.

PM11:09am

Back in January

BE11:10am

Rebased where? There's a certain amount of soft guidance involved in today's update that -- were we cynical, which we're not! -- might appear designed to pull the consensus lower ahead of the formal guidance.

11:10 am
PM11:10am

hmm

BE11:10am

The Pearson conference call was a bit of a struggle. Let me quote.

BE11:10am

This is Coram Williams, Pearson CFO

11:10 am
PM11:10am

Go on

BE11:11am

The 2016 final dividend was around £280 million. And you'll remember that we have to contribute around £225 million to the pension fund as a result of the agreement we made with trustees at the time of the formation of Penguin Random House.

BE11:11am

Super. Go on .....

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Now there are clearly other moving parts in addition to those items to get you to year end net debt, but together with the capital raised and retained in today's transaction, the outcome should be that full year net debt comes in below £800 million before the impact of foreign exchange. At the same time, as we issued our exit notice from Penguin Random House in January, we've also said that we'd rebase the dividend, reflecting the challenging market environment, our desire to maintain a strong balance sheet and ensure significant capacity to invest in our business.

BE11:11am

..... uh?

BE11:11am

We'll declare our interim dividend on August 4, along with our interim results, but it will be in line with the policy framework that we've laid out in today's statement. That is for sustainable and progressive dividend, which is comfortably covered by the earnings of our business, excluding any contribution from Penguin Random House and which can grow as our business grows into the opportunities in global education. As you can see from the slide, the contribution from Penguin Random House and the EPS guidance we gave you in January was around 15p.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

........ okay, so it's a new framework on the divi?

BE11:12am

Could you tell us more, Coram?

BE11:12am

I think what we've tried to do this morning is to lay out that framework for how to think about it. Clearly, we are aiming for a sustainable and progressive dividend, which is comfortably covered by our earnings base, excluding Penguin Random House, because we continue to see Penguin Random House as an economic stake rather than a strategic stake. We told you PRH is about 15p in the guidance this year. Take the midpoint of that guidance back to an earnings base of 37p, so 50p to the midpoint of the guidance, less the 15p PRH, 37p of earnings, which need to comfortably cover the dividend, we will confirm the exact amount at interims when we are talking about the interim results. But I think you should have seen that comfortably covered means a little bit more than 2x. And we'll confirm the number when we get to the half-year results.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

.............. So ..................... If you chew through all that you seem to emerge with a 15p divi.

BE11:12am

Which is quite a bit lower than a lot of the City expect.

PM11:13am

So what was a 6% yielding stock is gonna be a 2% yeilder going forward

11:13 am
PM11:13am

Marvellous

BE11:13am

That's the worry ... And remember that Pearson's owned quite widely by income funds, who appreciate the steady cash generation of household names like Economist, FTSE, the FT and Penguin.

BE11:13am

Wait, hang on .....

11:13 am
BE11:14am

... who appreciate the steady cash generation of household names like Edexcel, Sistema Educacional Brasileiro and Meximerica Media.

PM11:14am

hahahahaha

PM11:14am

Very good Bryce

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Let me cut to Liberum's Whittaker, who never shies away from an opportunity to push his (very successful) sell call.

PM11:15am

This guy has stuck to his guns

BE11:16am

Yup. Initiated as a seller, stayed seller all the way down. (And is also very communicative with us types, which is particularly appreciated while sellside goes into flux.)

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Our view is that the return of only £300m of the c. £780m raised via share buybacks suggests that Pearson realises it needs to protect its Balance Sheet, which management seemed to suggest was the case, noting the company wanted to protect its credit rating. Management stated that it would use some of the c. £780m net cash raised to pay down debt pointing to a $300m bond that matures in 2018. YE17E net debt is expected to be below £800m.

BE11:16am

Management stated that the dividend cover would be over 2x ex-the contribution of the PRH stake, which management indicated had a 15p impact on earnings. So taking the mid-point of their FY guidance, c. 52p, take off c. 15p for the PRH contribution, and assume a dividend cover slightly over 2x, and that would come out at c. 16p-17p. Since this would give just over a 2% dividend yield, that is likely to mean the stock loses its appeal to income funds, which had held it because of its formal dividend yield (from 2016). That could put pressure on the stock moving forwards.

PM11:17am

Whittake's target price is what? 360p or so?

11:17 am
BE11:17am

It is 360p. And that's founded, of course, on the main problem with Pearson: it's Pearson.

BE11:17am

The key problem we see with Pearson is its problems in the US Higher Education business, which makes up an estimated one-third of profits currently but will be more post-the PRH transaction and any sale of the US K-12 publishing business. Structural problems effectively driven by students refusing in greater numbers to pay very high prices for materials will put continued pressure on what has historically been a very high margin business for Pearson.

BE11:17am

Everyone else is a seller too, albeit less aggressively.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Numis.

BE11:18am

All in this transaction should not be a surprise having effectively been announced in January and with one buyer of the stake. The price looks sensible, and clearly this removes question marks around the Pearson balance sheet (our net debt falls to c.£200m post buyback); that said, we continue to question the long term value of selling some of the Group’s strongest assets (FT, PRH stake).

BE11:18am

Goldman.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

While we take no view on the likelihood of this transaction closing, and while we believe this announcement may take away some uncertainty around portfolio management and offers clarity on the dividend, we believe the company continues to face significant structural headwinds in the core business which we expect to weigh on earnings. In our view, a more radical portfolio transformation with proceeds invested in transformational M&A would better support Pearson pivoting its business away from these structural headwinds. We are Sell rated on Pearson.

BE11:19am

Oh, Shore are only holders!

BE11:19am

This morning’s announcement is not unexpected and is in keeping with PSON’s policy of simplifying and focusing its interests around its core learning businesses. We will revisit our financial forecasts following this morning’s call, but in the meantime maintain our cautious view reflecting the on-going challenges involved in negotiating the substantial organisational and cultural change required to realign the group to a digital future. On this basis we regard its current stock valuation (FY2017F and FY2018F P/E and DY ratios of 14.4x 3.1% and 13.2x 3.1% respectively) as full and maintain our Hold recommendation.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Anyway, that's that.

undefined
PM11:20am

And so to M&S

11:19 am
PM11:20am

Not a happy situation either

Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 325.98, down 13.02 (-3.84%), High: 341.00, Low: 323.40, Volume: 8.09m
PM11:20am

Q1s here https://www.invest...1707110700046538K/

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Food weak.

BE11:20am

Which is a new thing to worry about.

BE11:21am

The stuff about clothing and homewares stabilising had been pretty much flagged up earlier, with lots of previews talking about how fewer promotions would result in a higher quality of revenue.

11:21 am
PM11:22am

Stablising in the sense that it shrank slightly...

BE11:22am

Yep. So we get GM (as it used to be called) LFL -1.2%. Consensus was for -1%, albeit on a silly range.

BE11:22am

Range was -3.5% to +1.5%!

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Food's bad tho. LFL -0.1%. Consensus (tighter range) was +0.6%, and the most pessimistic forecast was for flat.

PM11:24am

Thing with M&S food (bar the sandwiches) is that it tastes of nothing

PM11:24am

How do they manage that?

11:24 am
PM11:24am

Is it because it's over-chilled or something

PM11:24am

It looks good, but tastes of nothing

BE11:25am

Hm ...... Since you mention it ..........

11:25 am
BE11:25am

There's a hint in there about losing the edge on the top end, and having to deliver "stronger promotions in a competitive market" and etc.

BE11:25am

However, my own theory is fridges.

BE11:25am

Every time I go into the West Hampstead M&S, at least four of the fridges are broken.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

They're running too high, they burn out, that has an impact on sales as well as the taste of the three-for-£10 Chicken Sag Marsala they sell.

BE11:27am

Anyway, let's drift back to something approximately more on subject.

BE11:27am

Barclays can summarise here.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

On Food, M&S says new stores continue to perform ahead of expectations. (M&S estimated the 1Q timing impact helped the reported LFL number by +0.7ppts, we had assumed +c0.5/+1.0ppts.) On Clothing, M&S says it continues to grow full price sales (+7%), with reduced discounting and no clearance sales in the quarter. The summer sale begins today, with terminal stock levels significantly lower than a year earlier. (The 1Q timing impact was +0.6ppts, we had assumed +c30bps). Overall LFL sales in the UK (Clothing and Food combined) fell by -0.5%, versus our estimate of 0.0%. Total sales growth in the international business fell by -4.0% in constant currency and rose +3.8% in reported currency (compared with our estimates of -3.0% and +3.0% respectively). Of the 53 international stores slated for closure, 28 have now been shut. There is no change to full-year guidance

BE11:28am

Overall, the sales numbers are modestly below expectations but the commentary is reasonably encouraging with new Simply Food stores performing well and the increase in full price clothing sales sounding positive for profit implications.

Valuation:

· M&S trades on a FY18E PE of 11.6x the sector average of 14.1x (inc Sainsbury on 12.0x and Morrison on 19.4x).

· Bear in mind that M&S offers a FCF yield of greater than 11% and a dividend yield of c5.5%.

PM11:29am

(Why Morrison's outlandish rating??)

11:02 am
PM11:02am

It may just be me, but it suddenly feels rather Tinhat ish

BE11:30am

(Though I forget detail of the story.)

BE11:30am

And Stifel ...........

11:30 am
BE11:30am

"There is more to do"... as CEO Steve Rowe kept repeating at this morning's analysts’ call. We couldn’t agree more: Food trade was weaker than expected, driven by range over-simplification and fewer promotional offers in a competitive environment; this was partially offset by Clothing trading performance, with Full price sales up 7%; FY18 Outlook remains uncertain, FX headwinds to be mitigated by sourcing reallocation, FY18 guidance unchanged.

BE11:30am

In Q1 Food performances were slightly below expectations as a result of a deeper than necessary range simplification in Simply Food stores with the intent to reduce waste (e.g., in protein, but we would add in the biscuits department too); This led to Food Q1 sales growth +4.5% (Stifel 6.2%), LFL -0.1% (consensus 0.6%); Management recognised the need for a better balance between product availability and waste reduction (hence the focus on improving ranges); as not unusual in the Food sector, Q1 trade was characterised by a strong competitive environment, and M&S admits they should have gone deeper with Food promos: we now expect more offers in Q2 and possibly for the rest of the year. New stores also played a part in the existing stores' sales cannibalisation (c.0.7%).

BE11:31am

........ what's Stifel's gripe with M&S biscuit department?

11:31 am
BE11:31am

They don't explain.

BE11:31am

FY18 Outlook remains uncertain: With FY18 guidance unchanged (full year gross margin for Clothing -25 to +25bps; Food -50 to 0bps; UK cost guidance +2.5% to 3.5%), the Group plans to mitigate FX headwinds through different sourcing allocation: more sourcing from Bangladesh and less from China, to quote a few examples. M&S recognises GfK data as reflective of its customer's shopping behaviour: overall customers feel positive about their personal financial situation, less on the general UK economy. The outlook remains uncertain, and the Group awaits post-summer evolutions. Rating HOLD reiterated.

BE11:32am

I'd argue that M&S wheaten crackers are among the best ways to spend £1.50 or £2 for two. I've no truck with M&S biscuit department.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Morgan Stanley as well.

BE11:33am

- Overall, this is a short and routine update, with management reiterating that its plans are on track and consensus forecasts unlikely to change much.

BE11:33am

That's Geoff Ruddell, who has every right to sound as bored as he does.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

- Today's statement makes clear that full year guidance remains unchanged and, having spoken with management, we are not anticipating much change in consensus full year forecasts today. According to Bloomberg, consensus is currently looking for M&S to generate FY 2018/19 Pre Tax Profits of £579m (equating to EPS of 29.4p). Company compiled consensus is slightly higher (£584m Pre Tax Profit).
- Based on last night's closing price and existing consensus forecasts, M&S is trading on 11.5x Cal 2018 earnings, 5.9x EV/EBITDA and offering a dividend yield of 5.5%. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 11.6x, 7.4x and 4.5% respectively.

undefined
PM11:34am

It so depresses me that our readers shop at Lidl

11:34 am
PM11:34am

But we should leave supermarkets alone

PM11:35am

This Tracy tweet mentioned no the right tho

PM11:35am

Great story

11:35 am
PM11:35am

https://twitter.com/tracyalloway/status/884708516388384768

BE11:35am

!

PM11:35am

Underlying story here https://www.bloomb...th-their-groceries

11:35 am
PM11:35am

Among the sneakers, diapers and pet food for sale on Taobao, China’s biggest e-commerce platform, is a listing that may take up a little more space in the online shopping basket.

For 4.15 million yuan ($610,000), customers on the site owned by e-retailing giant Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. can bid for the debt of a steelmaker from Zhejiang, a coastal province in eastern China. The company has failed to pay back a 9.95 million-yuan loan, including interest, so a distressed asset manager is auctioning it off to the highest online bidder

BE11:36am

........... wow.

undefined
11:36 am
PM11:36am

Sheesh, Carillion

PM11:36am

Off another 17%

Carillion PLC (CLLN:LSE): Last: 96.52, down 20.59 (-17.58%), High: 119.70, Low: 95.62, Volume: 25.39m
11:37 am
BE11:37am

Brokers were saying it should've been off 50% yesterday, though maybe there might have been a bit of short closing supporting it.

BE11:38am

Also worth noting that Carillion is, or perhaps was, quite retail owned.

PM11:38am

Scorchedfingers

11:38 am
BE11:38am

And any only partly engaged punter picking up the morning papers will probably not be overly keen on holding now.

BE11:39am

There was the usual stuff in the editorial about all possible options, including a breakup ........

BE11:40am

.......... with Balfour Beatty mentioned as a plausible buyer, I assume for the services bit. That looks heroic to me, given the work Balfour had to do to cure its own ills.

11:40 am
PM11:40am

Yeah, with you on that

BE11:40am

And given the KPMG contract review is ongoing, the services bit could well be the next shoe to drop.

BE11:41am

(@ROTR: it'd be polite if you didn't draw in other media to the conversation.)

11:41 am
BE11:42am

So ....... to expect anything other than a rescue rights from here relies on optimism.

BE11:42am

Want some numbers? Here's Peel Hunt.

BE11:42am

While the involvement of KPMG provides some reassurance
over current provisioning, we believe that there is still a risk of
further exceptionals, a significant equity raise and we continue to
have underlying trading concerns. We have materially reduced
estimates and the shares are best avoided until management
provides further insight at the time of interims.

11:42 am
BE11:43am

Assuming there are no material changes to the current assumptions, Carillion will have FY2017 average net debt of between £775m and £800m (implying H2 2017 average ND c£900m). We estimate that peak net debt could be c£200m higher than this. Current facilities of £1.5bn (first major maturity in 2019) look adequate in the short term (covenants are calculated at period ends) even if the receivable write downs are not recovered. However, if we add in the reverse factoring (£412m, but in our view likely to get bigger if supply chain confidence weakens) and the net pension deficit (£587m), the investor worries are clear. If we assume the support services business can comfortably support 2x ND/EBITDA (c£400m on revised estimates) and that Construction should be ungeared (given positive working capital), once we allow for balance sheet assets (c£50m), Carillion probably needs to raise c£500m through disposals and an equity raise.

BE11:43am

A reminder that support services, where guidance hasn't changed, is nearly three quarters of EBITDA.

BE11:44am

There's going to be a readthrough, one imagines, from the warning limiting Carillion's ability to win new contracts.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

(@DJ: Thumbs up )

BE11:45am

In that context, £500m might begin to look a wee bit low.

BE11:45am

Stifel .............

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Going forward the major issue becomes what happens to the net debt profile? The £845m provision is taken as an exceptional to which we expect smaller amounts to be added for deeper restructuring and possibly amounts for small contracts outside the KPM review. There is likely to be some recovery against the provision. At face value, this would imply that net will trend higher: offsetting are additional cost savings, more efficient collections, the benefit of cutting the dividend (£80m a year), tax shielding of UK profit and disposal proceeds (guided to c.£125m). Other factors include effects from restricting the early payment facility and adjustment to pension scheme funding post the in-progress triennial review.
Guidance is for end 2018 net debt slightly lower than at the half year (£695m). This follows the usual pattern of strong working capital collection into period ends: our estimate is for year-end net debt of £481m (before disposal proceeds beyond the initial £13m for 50% of the Oman JV), including sweeping assumptions for one-off costs and working capital outflow. Debt covenants are principally period end net debt less than 3.5x EBITDA and 3.5x cash flow interest cover. Debt is sourced under private placements and in largest part from a banking facility with maturity November 2020. Our revised EBITDA estimate gives available facility on the EBTIDA covenant of c.£900m.

BE11:47am

The blurry figures mean "the only practicable way to view valuation is through a sum of the parts approach", says Stifel.

BE11:48am

11:48 am
PM11:48am

Lot of guess work in there I fear

BE11:48am

Indeed. It's through that already, yet it's still not much of a discount.

undefined
11:48 am
PM11:49am

Hey, what level did we open our virtual short in Snap! at?

PM11:49am

Think it was around $22

PM11:49am

Overnight quote was $16.50

11:49 am
PM11:49am

This was so clear to us -- you just had to ask the kids.

PM11:50am

They all stopped using Snap when Facebook copied the stories tech

PM11:50am

I see Morgan Stanley have come out with their hands up

11:50 am
PM11:50am

Assume they were on the float. The rest of Wall St certainly was

PM11:50am

But now...

PM11:51am

Downgrade to EW as SNAP's ad product is not evolving/improving as quickly as we expected and Instagram competition is increasing. We cite four challenges that are proving more difficult to overcome than expected, and map four ways SNAP might improve forward growth. We lower our PT to $16 from $28.

11:51 am
PM11:51am

SNAP's Ad Products Are Taking Longer to Improve/Evolve Than We Expected and Instagram Competition Is Increasing. We have been wrong about SNAP's ability to innovate and improve its ad product this year (improving scalability, targeting, measurability, etc.) and user monetization as it works to move beyond "experimental" ad budgets into larger branded and direct response ad allocations. We also believe user growth trends have also been modestly weaker than expected, though time spent per user (now at 30+ minutes/day) has been strong. On competition, we believe Instagram has become more aggressive in competing for SNAP's ad dollars. As such, we see SNAP ad revenue growth being materially slower than we previously expected, and we lower our '17/'18 revenue forecasts by 7%13%. Our lower revenue flows through at a ~80% decremental operating margin, which reduces our '17'18 adjusted EBITDA forecasts by 6%/36% (see Exhibits 2 and 3). This causes our DCF-based PT to fall by ~40%, to $16 from $28. We move to EW and will monitor four areas of innovation which could improve SNAP's ad product and advertiser demand. For now, though, we are 9%12% below Street '17'18 revenue and 16%/76% below on adj EBITDA (see Exhibit 4).

PM11:51am

Have another block of that

PM11:52am

Larger than Expected Challenges. First, our latest industry conversations indicate many advertisers are struggling to develop SNAP ad units with sufficient completion rates and consistent return on investment. Lower ROI holds back incremental ad dollars (see Exhibit 5). Second, we believe that SNAP's ad ROI measurability has not improved as much as we had hoped or as much as expected by agencies this year...and that it remains lower than at other platforms (like Facebook and Instagram). This also holds back advertisers' willingness to increase ad budgets. Third, SNAP's self-serve automated bidding platform (which is intended to move beyond direct ad sales) is not scaling as quickly as we expected, as we initially thought the product would be fully launched in early 2017. We now do not expect it to scale until 4Q:17 or early 2018. Fourth, we believe Instagram is likely to be more disruptive than previously expected as our industry conversations indicate that Instagram is giving advertisers sponsored lenses for free. This is troubling for SNAP's forward ad growth given Instagram's scale (450mn+ estimated daily active users, compared to SNAP's 166mn), SNAP's current $15+ CPMs on lenses, and the fact that we estimate sponsored lenses and similar products make up approximately 50% of SNAP's ad revenue.

11:52 am
PM11:52am

Brian Nowak the analyst there

PM11:52am

What a heist this thing has proved to be

BE11:53am

At risk of repeating myself, I continue to argue that Snap IPO was a trial balloon for the reinvention of the equity markets as a crowdfunded form of venture capital, not an actual IPO.

11:53 am
PM11:53am

Yep -- and a sizeable one at thtat

BE11:53am

The price has been predictably terrible. But that was never the point. The float was to try and create an alternative exit route for insiders that didn't require a slug of cash from Google, Amazon or Facebook.

BE11:54am

And it kinda worked! Though it's made it more difficult for the next guy.

11:54 am
undefined
BE11:55am

(@Soundbuy: I was in that stupid shopping centre next to St Paul's yesterday. Next was the only clothes retailer not to be on 50% off, and was empty as a consequence. They seem to have lost all agility. It's odd.)

BE11:55am

So, in terms of requests ............. Galliford Try mentioned.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Year-end update solid.

Galliford Try PLC (GFRD:LSE): Last: 1,259, up 92 (+7.88%), High: 1,272, Low: 1,208, Volume: 483.14k
BE11:57am

....... because it's a housebuilder, in part, and we know how that cartel works. Construction side also going okay as a secondary consequence.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Here's Canaccord.

BE11:57am

Reassuring trading update confirms that the group has enjoyed a strong underlying performance with profits expected to be towards the upper end of the consensus range. Importantly the update confirms that the group expects to pay dividends in line with previous guidance. Linden Homes and Partnerships & Regeneration are expected to deliver good growth with the newer contracts in Construction also performing well. There is no change in the recent £98m of exceptional items recently posted in the Construction division. Modest net cash is expected at the end of June and average net debt of c.£250m has been better than previously guided. Management confirms that it is well positioned to deliver against its 2021 strategic targets. Shares should bounce today as they enjoy a relief rally that management is committing to the dividend guidance and with consensus likely to edge up for FY2017 and looks well supported for FY2018. Shares have de-rated recently with valuation now looking compelling with a dividend yield of over 8%.

BE11:58am

Update Summary
Linden Homes - is expected to report a strong performance for the full year. Completions were up by +7% to 3,296 and margins are expected to move ahead. The group confirmed that it has a strong forward order book to carry into the next financial year at £373m.
Partnerships & Regeneration - saw a strong performance with both revenue and margins higher on higher margin mixed tenure work. The order book increased by +23% to £1.05bn.
Construction - Management confirmed that the underlying business continues to perform well. The construction order book is strong at £3.5bn with 84% of next year's revenue secured.
The recent review of legacy contracts in Construction resulted in a £98m non-recurring charge. This has not changed.
The group confirms that it expects to pay a dividend in line with guidance after reviewing its financial and cash position.
Group outlook for FY2018 and future years is unchanged.

11:57 am
BE11:58am

Valuation
The shares trade on a FY2018E PE and EV/EBITDA multiple of c.7 times and 5.5 times respectively. 2018E P/NAV multiple is c.1.6 times with a dividend yield of c.8%.

PM11:58am

Not surprised the stock has bounced!

BE11:59am

(@Boncoeur: sure, it's handy when you've got a meeting and spilt doubanjiang on your shirt. But it also squats between St Paul's and Bow like an uninvited, half-populated satellite that broke loose from Bluewater.)

12:00 pm
PM12:00pm

(There's a bar and restaurant on the roof terrace. But both are very poor. Shame really.)

BE12:00pm

(The Ramsay place and the Oliver JV? Yeah, they're rubbish.)

BE12:00pm

(Though handy for Panmure Gordon.)

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

(Oh.)

BE12:01pm

HSBC!

BE12:02pm

We continue to value the Linden Homes business on the same Brexit-risked 2020e returns on assets/EV/IC derivation that we use for all the UK Housebuilders. This is included within a sum-of-the-parts (SOTP). Other features of our SOTP value the Construction business on an 8.0x EBITA multiple of 2020 estimated divisional EBITA discounted back to today. We have applied an 8.0x multiple to Partnerships. The prospective 7%+ dividend yield remains attractive, and we reiterate our Buy rating.
